column1: abstract = {Due to the prevalence of group activities on social networks
column2: group recommendations have received an increasing number of attentions. Most group recommendation methods concentrated on dealing with persistent groups
column3: while little attention has paid to ephemeral groups. Ephemeral groups are formed ad-hoc for one-time activities
column4: and therefore they suffer severely from data sparsity and cold-start problems. To deal with such problems
column5: we propose a pre-training and fine-tuning method called GBERT for improved group recommendations
column6: which employs BERT to enhance the expressivity and capture group-specific preferences of members. In the pre-training stage
column7: GBERT employs three pre-training tasks to alleviate data sparsity and cold-start problem
column8: and learn better user representations. In the fine-tuning stage
column9: an influence-based regulation objective is designed to regulate user and group representations by allocating weights according to each member's influence. Extensive experiments on three public datasets demonstrate its superiority over the state-of-the-art methods for ephemeral group recommendations.}

column1: abstract = {As a step beyond traditional personalized recommendation
column2: group recommendation is the task of suggesting items that can satisfy a group of users. In group recommendation
column3: the core is to design preference aggregation functions to obtain a quality summary of all group members' preferences. Such user and group preferences are commonly represented as points in the vector space (i.e.
column5: where multiple user embeddings are compressed into one to facilitate ranking for group-item pairs. However
column8: lack adequate flexibility and capacity to account for the multi-faceted user preferences. Also
column9: the point embedding-based preference aggregation is a less faithful reflection of a group's decision-making process
column10: where all users have to agree on a certain value in each embedding dimension instead of a negotiable interval. In this paper
column11: we propose a novel representation of groups via the notion of hypercubes
column12: which are subspaces containing innumerable points in the vector space. Specifically
column13: we design the hypercube recommender (CubeRec) to adaptively learn group hypercubes from user embeddings with minimal information loss during preference aggregation
column14: and to leverage a revamped distance metric to measure the affinity between group hypercubes and item points. Moreover
column15: to counteract the long-standing issue of data sparsity in group recommendation
column16: we make full use of the geometric expressiveness of hypercubes and innovatively incorporate self-supervision by intersecting two groups. Experiments on four real-world datasets have validated the superiority of CubeRec over state-of-the-art baselines.}

column5: the independent view severely suffers from the cold-start problem when making recommendations for occasional groups that are temporally formed by a set of users and have few interactions on items. Actually
column7: users and items are interdependent because they interact with one another. The interdependencies constitute an interaction graph that provides multiple views to model the embeddings of groups
column8: users and items from their interacting counterparts to improve recommendation for occasional groups. To this end
column10: named GAME to learn the Graphical and Attentive Multi-view Embeddings (i.e.
column12: users and items from the independent view and counterpart views based on the interaction graph. In the counterpart views
column14: user or item is aggregated from the interacting counterparts based on an attention mechanism that derives the adaptive weight for each counterpart. For instance
column15: a user's embedding may be aggregated from her interacting items or groups. Further
column16: GAME applies neural collaborative filtering to investigate the interactions between the multi-view embeddings of groups (or users) and items for group recommendation. Finally
column17: we conduct extensive experiments on two real datasets. The experimental results show that GAME outperforms other state-of-the-art models

column1: abstract = {We study the problem of making item recommendations to ephemeral groups
column2: which comprise users with limited or no historical activities together. Existing studies target persistent groups with substantial activity history
column3: while ephemeral groups lack historical interactions. To overcome group interaction sparsity
column4: we propose data-driven regularization strategies to exploit both the preference covariance amongst users who are in the same group
column5: as well as the contextual relevance of users' individual preferences to each group.We make two contributions. First
column6: we present a recommender architecture-agnostic framework GroupIM that can integrate arbitrary neural preference encoders and aggregators for ephemeral group recommendation. Second
column7: we regularize the user-group latent space to overcome group interaction sparsity by: maximizing mutual information between representations of groups and group members; and dynamically prioritizing the preferences of highly informative members through contextual preference weighting. Our experimental results on several real-world datasets indicate significant performance improvements (31-62\% relative NDCG@20) over state-of-the-art group recommendation techniques.}

column1: abstract = {This paper proposes Medley of Sub-Attention Networks (MoSAN)
column2: a new novel neural architecture for the group recommendation task. Group-level recommendation is known to be a challenging task
column3: in which intricate group dynamics have to be considered. As such
column4: this is to be contrasted with the standard recommendation problem where recommendations are personalized with respect to a single user. Our proposed approach hinges upon the key intuition that the decision making process (in groups) is generally dynamic
column6: a user's decision is highly dependent on the other group members. All in all
column7: our key motivation manifests in a form of an attentive neural model that captures fine-grained interactions between group members. In our MoSAN model
column8: each sub-attention module is representative of a single member
column9: which models a user's preference with respect to all other group members. Subsequently
column10: a Medley of Sub-Attention modules is then used to collectively make the group's final decision. Overall
column11: our proposed model is both expressive and effective. Via a series of extensive experiments
column12: we show that MoSAN not only achieves state-of-the-art performance but also improves standard baselines by a considerable margin.}

title = ""Towards creating a non-synthetic group recommendation dataset""
abstract = ""Recommender systems can be useful in group settings
column2: e.g. when choosing a movie to watch with a group. However
column3: while considerable research in group recommendation has been performed
column4: we still lack truly ecological datasets on group recommendations in real life consumption scenarios. Much of the existing work considers hypothetical consumption scenarios
column7: but no actual group consumption takes place in which situational differences per group are taken into account. In this paper
column8: we outline a vision for acquiring more realistic and ecological group consumption data
column9: based on a crowdsourcing application that will acquire individual ratings per group consumption event. We discuss various design decisions that will allow us to gather these ratings effectively from a large group of people
column10: and demonstrate and evaluate the viability of our approach towards reaching group consensus through rating session simulations.""
